One of the advantages of electrochemistry is that if even a part of that can follow the load directly or have some kind of buffer it can be a flexible way to you know use excess grid electricity to store hydrogen and then be able to feed it at different time scales and so the modes of operation for those things are not only continuous high temperature and large scale I think some of the flexibility that we gain in electrochemistry is we can scale things down which isn't always seen as an advantage but we can scale them down and flexible. So I think if we think about the way we operate these things are centralized they're really big and then we send everything away but electrochemistry can make smaller subunits that can be much more flexible.
